newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai rice steady, trade hopes for Philippine deal.
newsitem.headline: Thai rice steady, trade hopes for Philippine deal.

text.p: Thai rice prices were quietly steady this week with the market hopeful that Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchayudh's visit to Manila next week could seal a rice sale to the Philippines, trade sources said on Thursday.
Apart from recent buying from Malaysia and modest orders from regular customers, there were no new leads in the market, they told Reuters.
"Buyers still find our prices unattractive and turned to countries like Pakistan whose prices are still lower than ours despite a recent surge," said one trader.
"The amount of rice available in the market is also lower-than-expected...perhaps by hoarding as well," he said.
Industry sources said they expected the Philippines to ink a rice deal with Thailand during an official visit by Chavalit to Manila from January 29-30.
"Now that the Philippines have got the result of their rice survey, they are probably ready to order," said another trader.
The price of Thai benchmark 100 percent grade B this week was steady at US$380- $400 per tonne FOB Bangkok and fragrant 100 percent grade rice was unchanged at $620-$630.
Malaysia bought 20,000 tonnes of glutinous rice and 100 percent grade B rice from Thailand in a recent tender for February-March shipment, trade sources said.
Saudi Arabia also made enquiries but did not buy due to high prices, they said.
"We expect the price to nudge lower if buying interest is this thin," the trader said.
